As will be noted, many of these seminars and workshops had to be conducted by
the NAEB itself, with funds from. the W. K. Kellogg and the Ford Foundations,
because of the absence, in educational institutions, of mechanism,
courses, personnel, and curricula for tills type of training. In this role,
however, the NAEB has sought to serve mainly as a catalyst and example
to provide the stimulus for the introduction of such courses in the curricula
of educational institutions, themselves. To supplement this catalytic
effort, in recent years, grants-in-aid were awarded to colleges and uni¬
versities to permit them to up-grade radio and television workshops they
were by 1958 beginning to hold, by adding outstanding consultants or staff
members to what they would otherwise have been able to do.
The results of these efforts, particularly in the areas of production,
programming and technical operation, are now encouragingly apparent.
As this objective approaches realization, as it now does. In nearly all
areas except the training of teachers —* both those who broadcast and
those who utilize broadcast-lessons — in accordance with the uncompromising
standards which the NAEB has sought to establish by example, the NAEB
can once again concentrate on the achievement of its role as a professional
association of these professionally-trained individuals with the highest
standards which a respected profession can devise. This involves the
development of standards, qualifications and classifications for indi¬
vidual NAEB professional membership as described later in this document.
